;; page #00 of RAM


          fn09DD_row 
0100:C000 0000   defw 0000   
          fn09E3_row 
0100:C002 0000   defw 0000   
          fn09A1_row 
0100:C004 0000   defw 0000   
          fn097D_row 
0100:C006 0000   defw 0000   
          fn09E9_row 
0100:C008 0000   defw 0000   
          fn0935_row 
0100:C00A 0000   defw 0000   
          fn098F_row 
0100:C00C 0000   defw 0000   
          fn_mask 
0100:C00E 0000   defw 0000

0100:D3F0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D400 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
;; end of lcdbuff



;; When fontbuff holds a single char, the format is: 
;;   pixwide_byte, pixhigh_byte, byteswide_byte, then the bitmap data.
;;
;; When fontbuffer holds icon data, 1st 2 bytes are word: 
;;   width_word, height byte  (right after dispatchme)
;; 
;;   And then the width & height are overwritten with a single row of 
;;   icon pixels (one after each call to readdispatch). 
;;
          fontbuff.charwidth 
0100:D410 00     defb 00     
          fontbuff.charheight 
0100:D411 00     defb 00     
          fontbuff.charbyteswide_or_iconheight 
0100:D412 00     defb 00     
          fontbuff.charbitmap 
0100:D413 00000000000000000000000000 .............
0100:D420 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D430 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D440 0000   ..

          icon_num_bytes_wide 
0100:D442 0000   defw 0000   
          icon_bitmap_ptr 
0100:D444 0000   defw 0000   ;; points at the data for icon (not in buffer)
                            ;; advances one pixel row at a time, as each row 
                            ;; is copied to fontbuffer.

;; I am renaming this from cursorbyte to bytecursor.  I hope it does not
;; just confuse me more that way!!!  It is the address of the byte in
;; the LCD buffer that the "cursor" is pointing at.  And by cursor, I just
;; mean where writes will land, not a blinking thingy.
          bytecursor 
0100:D446 0000   defw 0000   

          source 
0100:D448 0000   defw 0000   

          LCD_Y 
0100:D44A 0000   defw 0000   

0100:D44C 00     nop         
0100:D44D 00     nop         

          lcdhalf 
0100:D44E 00     defb 00     
          lcd_bytecol 
0100:D44F 00     defb 00     

          x0 
0100:D450 0000   defw 0000   
          y0 
0100:D452 00     defb 00     
          x1 
0100:D453 0000   defw 0000   
          y1 
0100:D455 00     defb 00     
          delta_y 
0100:D456 00     defb 00     
          delta_x 
0100:D457 0000   defw 0000   

0100:D459 00     nop         

          clippedwidth 
0100:D45A 0000   defw 0000   
          clippedheight 
0100:D45C 00     defb 00     

          cursorbit 
0100:D45D 00     defb 00     

          time32 
0100:D45E 00000000 defl 00000000
          mightBeLastMailcheck??? 
0100:D462 00000000 defl 00000000
          mailcheck_interval 
0100:D466 00000000 defl 00000000
          hrrrmmmm??? 
0100:D46A 00     defb 00     
0006:4E98 set to 1 in moreinit
0006:5D63 set to par0 by somesortoftimer
0019:7F60 read, controls whether jump to batt check, or 
;;        if test powerdown timeout, with poss powerdown.





;; table2 is at D46B
;; 10 rows, 6 bytes each.
;; byte, word, timer_word, byte
;; I am renaming table2 to "Timer" to better reflect what it does.
;; The rtc interrupt increments the counter field of all ten of them.
;;
          Timer.bitz 
0100:D46B 00     defb 00     ;; bitz.0 means "in use" if 1, "available" if 0
                            ;; bitz.1 means "don't kill"
          Timer.limit 
0100:D46C 0000   defw 0000   
          Timer.counter 
0100:D46E 0000   defw 0000   
          Timer.Who 
0100:D470 00     defb 00     ;; matched with woztis

;; 9 more timers
0100:D471 00     defb 00     
0100:D472 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D474 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D476 00     defb 00     

0100:D477 00     defb 00     
0100:D478 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D47A 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D47C 00     defb 00     

0100:D47D 00     defb 00     
0100:D47E 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D480 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D482 00     defb 00     

0100:D483 00     defb 00     
0100:D484 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D486 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D488 00     defb 00     

0100:D489 00     defb 00     
0100:D48A 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D48C 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D48E 00     defb 00     

0100:D48F 00     defb 00     
0100:D490 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D492 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D494 00     defb 00     

0100:D495 00     defb 00     
0100:D496 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D498 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D49A 00     defb 00     

0100:D49B 00     defb 00     
0100:D49C 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D49E 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D4A0 00     defb 00     

0100:D4A1 00     defb 00     
0100:D4A2 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D4A4 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D4A6 00     defb 00     


;; table64, items entered via [0650]
;; Renamed to msgQ
;; 64 dec rows, 6 bytes per row
;; byte, byte, word, word
;;
;; This is an event queue.  Events are from keyboard, modem, timers, etc., and
;; also for internal communication between widgets or programs.  Some events
;; or signals are sent directly to recipient by the sender, and don't go thru 
;; this queue.
;; 
;; not sure if 3rd col is always a timer#, this might be a more general purpose
;; communication mech.  it's not always timer, renaming last two fields
;; to "this" & "that", to reflect a more general purpose.
;; 
;; AFAICT, the only references to tab64out are in init,
;; and exectasklists.  That would mean that the items in tab64 are always
;; meant for whoever is calling exectasklists.  It's kind of odd that it gets
;; called from more than one place, since one place it is called is the
;; main event loop.  Maybe there are other event loops, and they call this
;; to avoid hanging the mechanism for too long while doing a sub-function????
;; 
;; exectasklist checks all ten timers before it is done, and if any of them
;; are timed out, a message is added to tab64.  There are *lot's* of other
;; places that add items to tab64 too, so they are prob not all timeout msgs.
;;
;; signals:
;;   06 - keydown, top keyrow
;;   07 - keyup, top keyrow
;;   08 - keydown, normal key
;;   09 - keyup, normal key
;;   56 - download email??? [19:7f4c]
;;  
;; It also would appear that the tab64 fields correspond to the params of
;; execrow_tab30, 1 for 1:
;;
;; tab64.0, tab64.1, tab64.2, tab64.4
;; sp0008   sp0009   sp000a   sp000c
;; who      signal   this     that
;; 
;; byte,    byte,    word,    word
;;
          msgQ.who 
0100:D4A7 00     defb 00     ;; which app this event is for
          msgQ.signal 
0100:D4A8 00     defb 00     ;; event type (timer, key, etc.)
          msgQ.this 
0100:D4A9 0000   defw 0000   ;; 1st data (timer#, key scancode, etc.)
          msgQ.that 
0100:D4AB 0000   defw 0000   ;; 2nd data, often unused
;; the next 63 rows
0100:D4AD 000000 ...
0100:D4B0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D4C0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D4D0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D4E0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D4F0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D500 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D510 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D520 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D530 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D540 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D550 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D560 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D570 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D580 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D590 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D5A0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D5B0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D5C0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D5D0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D5E0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D5F0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D600 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D610 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D620 00000000000000 .......

          msg_Q_in 
0100:D627 00     defb 00     
          msg_Q_out 
0100:D628 00     defb 00     
          msg_Q_count 
0100:D629 00     defb 00     


;; This is the Qrec returned by exectasklists at the top of maineventloop.
          current_event.who 
0100:D62A 00     defb 00     
          current_event.signal 
0100:D62B 00     defb 00     
          current_event.this 
0100:D62C 0000   defw 0000   
          current_event.that 
0100:D62E 0000   defw 0000   


          LCDbuff_dirty 
0100:D630 00     defb 00     

          flagz 
0100:D631 00     defb 00     

          bootstate 
0100:D632 00     defb 00     

;; this is starting to look like one of the 20 byte thingies.
;; I think it might be refering to the whole screen, or at least the current
;; window.  The values are used to init other thingys, 
;; so this might be "the mother of all thingies"!!!  wow...
          somethingy.0_xa 
0100:D633 0000   defw 0000   
          somethingy.2_ya 
0100:D635 0000   defw 0000   
          somethingy.4_xd 
0100:D637 0000   defw 0000   
          somethingy.6_yd 
0100:D639 0000   defw 0000   
          somethingy.8_yt 
0100:D63B 00     defb 00     
          somethingy.9_yb 
0100:D63C 00     defb 00     
          somethingy.A_font 
0100:D63D 00     defb 00     
          somethingy.B_colorfillclip??? 
0100:D63E 00     defb 00     ;; bit0 = color  bit1 = filled  bit2 = clipped
          somethingy.somebox.x0 
0100:D63F 0000   defw 0000   
          somethingy.somebox.y0 
0100:D641 0000   defw 0000   
          somethingy.somebox.x1 
0100:D643 0000   defw 0000   
          somethingy.somebox.y1 
0100:D645 0000   defw 0000   



00  main????
01  inbox
02  outbox
03  creatnewmail
04     ;; address book
05  extras
06     ;; calculator
07     ;; calendar
09     ;; settings
08     ;; users
0A     ;; sent mail



;; The name table30 just refers to the fact that there are 30 rows.  Each
;; row is 7 bytes.  There is another table with 30 rows, 16 bytes per row,
;; that for the time being is labeled "tab16" for the simple fact that this
;; table was already "tab30".  The two are intimately related, but not on a 
;; row per row basis.  Seems entirely arbitrary that they both are 30 rows.
;; There is even a 3rd table with 30 rows, that I am calling "file handles".
;; At this time, I don't think there is any reason that any are 30 rows, other
;; than the programmer thought 30 was a big enough size for all of them. 
;; I could be wrong!
;;
;; Tab30 seems to have a row for each of several distinct programs.  It might
;; be that there is one for each major mode, like "inbox", "calculator",
;; "yahoo", "settings", etc.

;; table30, has 30 dec rows, 7 bytes each.
;;
;; param when func called(w, x, signal, par4, par6)
;; 
          tab30.ram_etc 
0100:D647 00     defb 00     ;; hi 4 bits are ram pg, lo bits somethin else
                            ;; xxxx x1xx means function is in dataflash!
                            ;; xxxx xx1x means wants events????
                            ;; xxxx xxx1 means maximize window?????
          tab30.funcaddr 
0100:D648 0000   defw 0000   ;; this is app event_handler address
          tab30.starttab16 
0100:D64A 00     defb 00     ;; this is starting widget index
          tab30.numrowstab16 
0100:D64B 00     defb 00     ;; this is number of widgets
          tab30.tab16row 
0100:D64C 00     defb 00     ;; this is focused widget
          tab30.lastretval??? 
0100:D64D 00     defb 00     ;; app state???? set to retval [6:435d]
;; 29 more rows...
0100:D64E 0000   ..
0100:D650 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D660 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D670 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D680 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D690 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D6A0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D6B0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D6C0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D6D0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D6E0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D6F0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D700 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D710 000000000000000000 .........

          wozthis 	(FYBER: must be current app #)
0100:D719 00     defb 00     
          tweedledee_oldwoz 
0100:D71A 00     defb 00     ;; last wozthis???
          tweedledum_newwoz 
0100:D71B 00     defb 00     ;; might be count for tab30??? prob not, it is
                            ;; set = to wozthis when wozthis is set. [6:4384]
                            ;; set to 0 right after init'ng tab30 (empty).


;; This is a table of what might turn out to be "windows" or "objects" or
;; "widgets".  Items in tab30 can be associated with many of these.  There
;; are fields in tab30 that delimit a range of tab16 items, but not every one 
;; in that range is neccessarily included.  There is a field in these 
;; items indicating "who" they go with that gets checked.  They can also be
;; marked inactive.
;;
;; 16 bytes per row, 30 dec rows
          Tab16.12listfunc 
0100:D71C 00     defb 00     ;; used as index to 12List
          tab16+1_ram_etc????? 
0100:D71D 0000   defw 0000   ;; xxxx xx1x = nogo (prevent changing current app)
          tab16.fh/str# 
0100:D71F 0000   defw 0000   ;; file handle number (or string#)
          tab16.font 
0100:D721 00     defb 00     
          tab16.x 
0100:D722 0000   defw 0000   ;; x
          tab16.y 
0100:D724 0000   defw 0000   ;; y
          tab16.xd 
0100:D726 0000   defw 0000   ;; deltax
          tab16.yd 
0100:D728 0000   defw 0000   ;; deltay
          tab16+E_who 
0100:D72A 00     defb 00     
          tab16.F_seq#/inuseflag?? 
0100:D72B 00     defb 00     ;; 0 means not used, otherwise seems to be seq#,
;;                              where 1st widget is 1, next 2, etc.
;; the rest of the rows for tab16
0100:D72C 00000000 ....
0100:D730 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D740 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D750 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D760 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D770 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D780 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D790 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D7A0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D7B0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D7C0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D7D0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D7E0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D7F0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D800 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D810 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D820 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D830 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D840 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D850 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D860 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D870 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D880 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D890 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D8A0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D8B0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D8C0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D8D0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D8E0 00000000000000000000000000000000 ................
0100:D8F0 000000000000000000000000 ............

          n_tab16???? 
0100:D8FC 00     defb 00     
;; this var is used:
;; 
;; At 5:474d it is compared with a tab30row#
;; At 5:6945  compared with a tab16row#
;; At 6:4FDA  init to 0
;; At 6:539f  sets to 30

          taskyyyy 
0100:D8FD 0000   defw 0000   

          taskzzzz 
0100:D8FF 0000   defw 0000   

          6List 
0100:D901 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D903 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D905 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D907 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D909 0000   defw 0000   
0100:D90B 0000   defw 0000   
          n6List 
0100:D90D 00     defb 00     


;; This is just a list of addresses of functions.
;; Each item in tab16 is associated with one of these.
;; It may be that these are handlers for different types of widgets 
;; in a window.  These are set to what appear to be fixed values during init.
;;
*** Signals ***

widget 4

0e  - create file???
0f  - close file???
10
11


          12List

0100:D910 0000   defw 0000

;; file handle table, 30 dec rows, 8 bytes per row
          fh.code 
0100:D926 00     defb 00     
          fh.page 
0100:D927 00     defb 00     
          fh.begin 
0100:D928 0000   defw 0000   
          fh.size 
0100:D92A 0000   defw 0000   ;; prob "end", not size???
          fh.positon 
0100:D92C 0000   defw 0000

;; Dunno what these 3 knuckleheads are for, but they are related.
;; The number in label is what they are inited to.
;; They are page & offsets, prob ram allocation????   
;;
          larry03 
0100:DA16 00     defb 00     ;; so, what is this one????  maybe it is the
          larry0000 
0100:DA17 0000   defw 0000   ;; beginning of "heap" space??????

          moe03 
0100:DA19 00     defb 00     ;; limit??????  (end of "heap" space?????)
          moe4000 
0100:DA1A 0000   defw 0000   

          curly03 
0100:DA1C 00     defb 00     ;; points to freespace in "heap"???
          curly0000 
0100:DA1D 0000   defw 0000   


          bit1_lgfont 
0100:DA1F 00     defb 00     ;; bit1 = use large font
                            ;; bit0 might be cursor enable???
          save_tab16row 
0100:DA20 00     defb 00     
          x_cursor 
0100:DA21 0000   defw 0000   
          y_cursor 
0100:DA23 0000   defw 0000   
          cursor_drawn_flag 
0100:DA25 00     defb 00     ;; #01 if cursor loc is inverted
          cursor_time 
0100:DA26 00000000 defl 00000000

;; 256 bytes, the current bookmark sector is loaded here.
;; Seems to overlap with some other vars
          bookmark_buffer???

;; This is a 1024 byte buffer.  It is used as an intermediate when copying
;; between two different pages of the virtual ram
